items.text: If an average of around 2000 people visit the supermarket each day and each round up around 1 to 5 cents, that would make around 10000 cents per day. That would be 100€, and if even more people visit the supermarket, that number would be even more.

Let’s say there are 2000 people hailing at the supermarket on average. Now it depends on where the supermarket is located; in my area, the nearest penny mostly loads of students shop there. I think students are less likely to donate as they normally are on a tight monthly budget. And some people pay with card. But if we assume that every second customer donates an average of five cents, a supermarket can collect 10€ a day.

If I assume that 40 customers per hour are at one checkout, and 15 of them round up, let’s say an average of 5 cents, that would mean 75 cents per hour. But, if we assume that there are 3 cashiers open (in a big supermarket, 2 in a smaller one), we already have 2.25€. That amount times the hours they’re open (let’s assume 12 hours, 8-20h) would come up to 27€ per day.

If we assume that the average shopper takes about five minutes to complete their shop and each consumer donates whatever the average of 1, 2 and 5 cents is, and we account for only half the people doing it, because Germans are stingy, we get the formula: (24x60)/5xthe average = some amount of money. Based off my gut feeling, I would wager that about thirteen euros per day would be raised.
If everyone was to actually round up, you could probably donate 100 Euros.

I like the idea of the small donations because it’s not much for everyone (everyone should be able to donate a few cents), but in total if millions of people do it daily, a big sum can come up! I think on an average day I’ll probably donate 50-80 cents. If one day is less - maybe because I don’t go shopping at all - the other day will be more perhaps. Also: I experienced this kind of donation in a Budni Store here at Am Sande where I donated 10 cents! :)

Firstly, an average day for a Deutsch supermarket will have to aggregate the foot traffic of 5 weekdays and 1 weekend day through a grocery store and consider the time of day and relative changes to the amount of people buying from a grocery store therein. I separate into 5 "classes" of the day, divided by importance and time: Morning: 8:00 - 10:29, Lunch: 10:30 - 13:59, Afternoon: 14:00 - 16:29, Evening: 16:30 - 18:59, Night: 19:00 - 22:00. Then, considering a population of about 83 million, I'd make a head estimate that about 10 million transactions are made in grocery stores in a day.

If a supermarket roughly makes 20,000€ a day and every second customer rounds up, I think the supermarket collects round about 500€ a day more or less. Depending on how busy it is and how many are rounding up.

I believe that if every customer participates in this project, the accumulative amount of donation would be considerable. Since some coins to most people are useless, that would definitely make a great difference in the community by helping the impoverished, vulnerable children, hence improving the general living standard.

To gather more accurate estimates for the "Germany rounds up" campaign, I examined industry reports from major grocery chains and market research organizations like Nielsen. These sources indicate that an average supermarket serves about 2,500 customers daily, with average customer spending around €30. If we assume a participation rate of 25% in the "round up" program, we would have approximately 625 customers participating. With an average rounded-up amount of €0.60 per transaction, the calculation becomes: 625 participants x €0.60 = €375. Therefore, based on these refined statistics, an average supermarket could collect around €375 daily through the campaign. This estimate accounts for customer behavior variations and utilizes reliable data sources to enhance accuracy. Analyzing different supermarkets' data would help in deriving an even broader understanding of variations by location or store type.

If we calculate the average grocery prices more precisely, say around €40, and still consider approximately 1,000 transactions daily, and assuming around 30% of customers round up their change, with each contributing an average of 15 cents, the total could remain close to €150. However, if customer participation is higher, or if the rounding amounts increase as prices fluctuate, it could potentially drive the total collected closer to €200 or even exceed it. Variables such as promotional days or local fundraising efforts might also lead to changes in this collection. Thus, while €150 could be a conservative estimate, €200 isn’t out of reach with a more engaged customer base.

The "Germany rounds up" initiative can potentially collect a significant amount of money daily across supermarkets. For instance, if we assume an average transaction value of €20, rounding up each transaction by €0.10 could mean an additional €0.10 from every customer. If a supermarket serves around 1,000 customers a day, that could lead to about €100 in donations daily. Across multiple supermarkets, this adds up quickly. Additionally, considering busy shopping days, the total could be even higher. Based on these estimations, the campaign effectively encourages community support while also addressing child poverty, making it a win-win solution. Overall, the cumulative potential could reach several million euros annually.

If 3000-5000 customers are supposed to visit the supermarket daily, each buying between 10-20 articles on average, and every article may be presumed to be in need of rounding, one may suppose that ca. 300-5000€ would be raised, with the true number probably being more on the lower end given most products cost ...€ and 99 cents. A possible average may be 4000 * 15 * 0.02 = 1200€.
around €10 to €30 in small coins per day with an average approximation of 20/day.

Assuming an average of one transaction every 5 minutes for the whole day, assuming the supermarket is open for 15 hours, there would be 180 transactions. Since not all customers will want to round up, we can assume an average of 2 cents rounded up per transaction, which would mean 360 cents, 3.6 euros per day. If every transaction was to be rounded up, the average number of cents per transaction would be (1+2+3+4+5+6+7+8+9+0)/10=4.5. This way, 8.10 euros would be collected per day on average.

In an average supermarket, let’s consider that 1,000 customers shop each day. If each customer donates an average of 50 cents by rounding up, that equates to $500 in daily donations. Over a month, this would amount to approximately $15,000, and in a year, around $180,000.

There are many possibilities and it's hard to tell how much money a supermarket would gain as we have to look at the number of people who buy groceries at the supermarket each day. We also have to consider how many people would want to round up and how much change the supermarket gains each time. We could maybe assume that 150 people go to the same supermarket a day (I don't know if this number of people is valid or logical) and 50 people choose to round up (up to) 10 cents. With that, the supermarket would end up gaining 500 cents, which means 5 euros, a day at maximum.

The "Germany rounds up" campaign is a clever way to address the issue of accumulating small change while also supporting a noble cause. If we consider an average supermarket with a busy foot traffic of about 1,000 customers per day, and assume around 30% of them choose to round up their purchases by about 0.50 euros, that could result in approximately 150 transactions contributing to the fundraising effort. This would lead to a potential collection of around 75 euros daily. Over a month, assuming consistent participation, this could translate to about 2,250 euros. With ongoing participation and increased awareness, the campaign could grow significantly over time, benefiting many children in need. It's an excellent example of how small actions can lead to substantial impacts.

In a typical German supermarket, around 1,000 to 1,500 customers shop per day. Only a portion of them choose to donate by rounding up, and a reasonable estimate is that about 15–25% participate. The average donation per customer is very small, usually between 1 and 10 cents, so using about 5 cents as an average is realistic. If 1,200 customers visit and 20% donate, that results in about 240 donations per day. Multiplying 240 by 5 cents gives roughly 12 euros. Even though this seems small, it adds up over time. In one month, a single supermarket can therefore collect between 300 and 600 euros. Across many participating stores nationwide, this becomes a substantial amount for charity.
